Article Title: Bill Gates daughter Phoebe Gates on how she took matters in her own hands and 'forced Bill Gates to ...'
Article Text: Microsoft founder Bill Gates has described himself as being shy and awkward. Bill Gates has talked about his shy and awkward phases in his memoir. And what helped change him, or kinda a change this behavior is her youngest daughter Phoebe Gates' persistence. Phoebe Gates claims to be on a mission to change this about Bill Gates from a young age. Having to grow up in the public eye herself being the daughter of one of the world's richest men, Phoebe shared in an episode of "Call Her Daddy" how Bill Gates is not much of a people person.Phoebe, the youngest of the three Gates children, described how she took it upon herself to help her father overcome his shyness. "I was like, 'No, if we're here, we're going to socialize. We gotta work this room, Bill" Phoebe told host Alex Cooper during the podcast.She recounted telling him at father-daughter dances. Phoebe said she'd "force my dad to go talk to all the other dads and daughters, and he would get nervous and leave" in some instances. Despite his occasional nervousness, she never let up. According to Phoebe, her family now jokes that life "would be so boring" without her extroverted personality.Phoebe also shared that she and her father share a competitive streak that can make family game nights intense. This drive comes out in full force when she brings home a new boyfriend. She described how Bill Gates can get "really nerve-wracking," sometimes even taking puzzle pieces out of a date's hands to fit them together himself.Cooper also asked her how she handled situations when people doubted her or just thought she was Bill’s daughter. "Fake it to you make it," she said during the podcast. "If I feel like I am my own person stepping into that room, because frankly, once you get inside a room, it doesn’t matter how you got here."She also acknowledged the immense privilege she grew up with, and recognized there were difficulties in getting out of her parent's shadows.
Article Summary: Microsoft founder Bill Gates has described himself as being shy and awkward. His youngest daughter, Phoebe Gates, shared how she helped him overcome this in an episode of "Call Her Daddy" She also shared that she and her father share a competitive streak that makes family game nights intense.

Article Title: Judge calls out 'stupidity' of 300 bankers of America's largest bank JP Morgan Chase while sentencing Charlie Javice, once called 'wonder' CEO
Article Text:
Charlie Javice, the 20-something women CEO who 'fooled' JP Morgan

What Charlie Javice's lawyers said in her defense





A Manhattan judge didn't hold back, using unusually blunt language to describe JP Morgan's bankers as victims of a massive fraud, but at the same time chiding them for their "stupidity". According to a report from Business Insider, US District Judge Alvin K Hellerstein sentenced fintech founder Charlie Javice to seven years in prison and ordered her to pay $287.5 million in restitution.It was halfway through the hearing that the judge began his scathing criticism of the bank's due diligence. "What consideration should be given for JPMorgan Chase's very poor due diligence?" Hellerstein asked. But he went on to add that Fraud remains a fraud "whether you outsmart someone who is smart or someone who is a fool."Javice, who once appeared on Forbes' "30 Under 30" list, was found guilty of defrauding America's largest bank JP Morgan Chase in the 2021 sale of her startup, Frank. The bank paid $175 million for the company, believing it had access to a database of 4 million college students. It was later revealed that Javice had fabricated the data, using a computer programmer to create a fake list of users.JP Morgan did not discover the fraud until a year after the acquisition was finalized, despite a team of 300 in-house diligence officers vetting the deal.The prosecution described Frank as "a crime scene," not a viable business.Javice, who had previously attracted high-profile investors, even managed to secure one-on-one meeting with JP Morgan CEO Jamie Dimon.During the sentencing, the judge was unswayed by the defense's argument that JP Morgan, a bank worth nearly $4 trillion, should have known better. In a striking statement, Judge Hellerstein declared that his job was "punishing her conduct and not JPMorgan's stupidity." He emphasized that "fraud remains a fraud, whether you outsmart someone who is smart or someone who is a fool."The defense had pointed to trial evidence showing that one bank executive had scoffed at the sale price, calling it "nothing." Yet, the judge insisted that blaming the victim, even a banking giant, was irrelevant. "Whether you outsmart someone who is indifferent or someone who is careful, it's the conduct," he said.
Article Summary: Charlie Javice sentenced to seven years in prison and ordered to pay $287.5 million in restitution. She was found guilty of defrauding JP Morgan Chase in the 2021 sale of her startup, Frank. The bank paid $175 million for the company, believing it had access to a database of 4 million college students. It was later revealed that Javice had fabricated the data.

Article Title: More than 90% companies have seen their AI investments failing and blame for this should go to ..., says study
Article Text:
MIT study says 95% of Gen-AI pilots at companies are failing





A new study has tried to reason the biggest complaint that majority of companies have with their AI investment -- that they give zero return. A recent MIT study had put the figure of AI investment failures at 95%. Now a study from researchers at consulting company BetterUp Labs, in collaboration with Stanford Social Media Lab, has reasoned the AI failure with a new term -- "workslop". The study coins the new term to describe low-quality, AI-generated work: “Workslop.”Published in the Harvard Business Review, the research highlights how Workslop may explain why 95% of organizations experimenting with AI report no return on investment. Workslop, defined as “AI-generated work content that masquerades as good work, but lacks the substance to meaningfully advance a given task,” is often unhelpful, incomplete, or missing critical context. The researchers warn that it shifts the burden downstream, forcing others to interpret, correct, or redo the work.The researchers also conducted an ongoing survey of 1,150 full-time, U.S.-based employees, with 40% of respondents saying they’d received Workslop in the past month.To combat Workslop, researchers urge workplace leaders to model intentional AI use and establish clear guidelines for acceptable practices. “Leaders must set guardrails around norms to ensure AI contributes meaningfully,” the study advises.The findings highlight the need for thoughtful integration of AI tools to avoid creating more work rather than less.A recent MIT study indicates that 95% of organizations studied get zero return on their AI investment. The study said that 95% of organizations found zero return despite enterprise investment of $30 billion to $40 billion into GenAI. MIT researchers are said to have studied 300 public AI initiatives to try and suss out the "no hype reality" of AI's impact on business.
Article Summary: A recent MIT study indicates that 95% of organizations studied get zero return on their AI investment. Now a study from researchers at consulting company BetterUp Labs has reasoned the AI failure with a new term -- "workslop" The study coins the new term to describe low-quality, AI-generated work.

How Google determined the winners of Nano Banana hackathon







Google DeepMind has announced the 50 winners of its recent Nano Banana Hackathon. The company is awarding the contest winners non-monetary prizes totalling $400,000. The 48-hour competition, which ran from September 6 to September 8, received 832 project submissions. Each of the 50 winning projects received a prize package that included $5,000 in Gemini API credits, $1,000 in Fal credits, and 11 million Eleven Labs credits valued at approximately $2,000. Google also provided a special technology prize for submissions that demonstrated outstanding technical achievement using Eleven Labs or Fal technologies.In a thread of posts shared on the social media platform X (earlier Twitter), Google announced the names and the projects of each winner and wrote:As the name implies, participants were challenged to create a product, application, or demo using Google’s Gemini 2.5 Flash Image model, popularly known as Nano Banana. This new image generation and editing tool, developed by Google, enhances the Gemini app’s editing experience by allowing users to create multiple variations from a single photo or combine ideas from different images.The hackathon went beyond basic text-to-image generation, asking participants to develop innovative concepts, leverage the model’s strengths, and build apps that could power dynamic storytelling, boost e-commerce, automate creative workflows, and enable the next wave of natural language photo editors, according to Google DeepMind.To support this, Google introduced a special Gemini API tier with a limit of 20 images per minute and 500 requests per project daily. Submissions had to be hosted publicly on Kaggle and include a demo video of up to two minutes to showcase the project’s “wow” factor.Entries were judged with 10% weight given to the quality of the demo video, 40% to innovation and the “wow” element, and the remaining points split across technical execution, functionality, and potential impact.Google highlighted several winners in a social media post. Among them, LifeTrace Timeline transformed raw location data into a personal diary for reflecting on daily experiences. ArtLens blended AI with art history to reimagine famous paintings as real-world scenes. Another standout, ForgeOne, introduced an AI-driven system for automated creative workflows that evaluates and refines its own outputs against professional standards.
Article Summary: Google DeepMind has announced the 50 winners of its Nano Banana Hackathon. The company is awarding the contest winners non-monetary prizes totalling $400,000. The 48-hour competition, which ran from September 6 to September 8, received 832 project submissions.

Article Title: Spotify’s Daniel Ek steps aside as CEO, takes on executive chairman role
Article Text:
FILE - Spotify founder and CEO Daniel Ek poses for a photo in Stockholm, Sweden, June 18, 2009. (Janerik Henriksson, TT News Agency, File)

Ek’s statement



Leadership evolution



Board and co-CEOs React







Spotify founder and CEO Daniel Ek has announced that he is stepping down from his role as the CEO effective from January 1, 2026. Ek will transition to the position of executive chairman, while longtime executives Gustav Söderström and Alex Norström will take over as co-CEOs. They will report to Daniel Ek and will also serve on the company’s Board of Directors subject to shareholder approval.In a letter to employees, Ek reflected on Spotify’s journey from a startup to a global audio leader with more than 700 million users:“I always believed that Spotify could play an important role in revolutionizing listening around the world, and with more than 700 million users, we’ve truly charted a new course bringing creativity to every corner of the globe,” said Daniel Ek.“Over the last few years, I’ve turned over a large part of the day-to-day management and strategic direction of Spotify to Alex and Gustav–who have shaped the company from our earliest days and are now more than ready to guide our next phase. This change simply matches titles to how we already operate. In my role as Executive Chairman, I will focus on the long arc of the company and keep the Board and our co-CEOs deeply connected through my engagement.This move by Daniel Ek formalises the leadership structure which has been in place since 2023 with Söderström (Chief Product & Technology Officer) and Norström (Chief Business Officer) already steering much of Spotify’s strategic and operational direction. As Executive Chairman, Ek will focus on capital allocation, long-term strategy, and board engagement, in a role modeled after the European chairman system.Woody Marshall, Lead Independent Director of Spotify’s Board, said the transition had been in planning for years: “We have tremendous confidence in Alex and Gustav as they step into these roles… We are also thrilled that Daniel will be actively involved, giving Spotify both founder-led strategic stewardship and mentorship to the co-CEOs.”In a joint statement, Söderström and Norström said: “We’ve worked together a very long time and have seen Spotify through many different chapters… While we bring different experiences and perspectives to the CEO role, we both have a strong bias to action and can’t wait to get started knowing that we will have Daniel’s full partnership and ongoing support.”
Article Summary: Spotify founder and CEO Daniel Ek has announced that he is stepping down from his role as the CEO effective from January 1, 2026. Ek will transition to the position of executive chairman, while longtime executives Gustav Söderström and Alex Nor Ström will take over as co-CEOs. They will report to Daniel Ek and will also serve on the company’s Board of Directors.

Article Title: Optus outage in Australia: What we know about the fatal triple-0 emergency call failures
Article Text:
Company knew of problems hours before resolution

Optus’ previous failures raise accountability questions





Australia's second-largest telecommunications provider Optus is facing mounting pressure after a 13-hour emergency services outage led to four deaths and caused 600 triple-zero calls to fail across multiple states. The September 19 network failure has prompted government investigations and renewed calls for accountability from the embattled telco.The outage primarily affected South Australia, Western Australia, and the Northern Territory, with some impact also recorded in far western New South Wales near the SA border, according to Reuters reporting. CEO Stephen Rue confirmed that established processes were not followed during a network firewall upgrade that began at 12:30 AM Thursday and lasted until approximately 1:30 PM (local time).Four deaths have been linked to the incident, though South Australian police later clarified that an eight-week-old boy's death in Gawler West was "unlikely" to have been caused by the outage delay. A 68-year-old Adelaide woman and two men aged 74 and 49 in Perth remain connected to the emergency services failure.The Australian Broadcasting Company (ABC) reported that Optus received multiple customer complaints about the triple-zero failure as early as 9 AM Thursday, with five customers contacting the call center about the outage.However, these concerns were not properly escalated, and government authorities weren't informed until after the issue was resolved.Communications Minister Anika Wells expressed "unbelievable disappointment" that Australia was "here again so quickly," referencing a similar 2023 incident. The Australian Media and Communications Authority (ACMA) chair Nerida O'Loughlin revealed her agency wasn't notified until more than 10 hours after the outage began, contrary to standard protocols.This marks the second major triple-zero outage for Optus in less than two years. The company was fined A$12 million in 2023 for failing to provide emergency call services to thousands during a nationwide outage and subsequently failing to conduct required welfare checks.The telecommunications giant, owned by Singapore Telecommunications, has faced a series of crises including a 2022 cyberattack affecting 9.5 million Australians and the 2023 outage that led to former CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin's resignation. Current CEO Stephen Rue took over in November 2024.Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, speaking from New York, declined to say whether Rue should resign but indicated the government has "action at its disposal" pending investigation results. ACMA has launched a formal investigation, with Optus potentially facing fines exceeding $10 million and additional penalties.The company has promised full cooperation with all investigations while conducting its own internal review, with results to be made public.
Article Summary: 13-hour emergency services outage led to four deaths and 600 triple-zero calls to fail. Optus received multiple customer complaints about the outage as early as 9 AM Thursday. Government authorities weren't informed until after the issue was resolved. This marks the second major triple- zero outage for Optus in less than two years.

Article Title: How an US government agency may have 'leaked' Apple's iPhone secret
Article Text:
Apple explicitly requested confidentiality for trade secrets

iOS26 now available: Things to know

Technical details could benefit competitors and repair shops







The Federal Communications Commission has accidentally published confidential iPhone 16e schematics online, despite Apple 's explicit request to keep the 163-page document sealed indefinitely. The leak, discovered Monday on the FCC's equipment authorisation database and mirrored by third-party site FCCID.io, exposes detailed electrical diagrams, chip configurations, antenna locations, and internal components that Apple warned could give competitors an "unfair advantage. "A cover letter dated September 16, 2024, shows Apple specifically asked the FCC to withhold the schematics from public view, stating they contain "confidential and proprietary trade secrets." The documents—clearly marked "Apple Proprietary and Confidential" on nearly every page—include block diagrams, electrical schematic diagrams, technical specifications, and tune-up procedures that Apple considers commercially sensitive even after product release.The leak likely resulted from an incorrect database setting during the certification filing process, according to reports from AppleInsider and 9to5Mac.Metadata indicates that both short-term and permanent confidentiality settings were marked as "no," contradicting Apple's written request and triggering automatic publication by FCCID.io.While the schematics hold little value for average consumers, they could significantly benefit hardware researchers, independent repair shops, and competing smartphone manufacturers. The documents reveal board-level component routing, signal pathways between major chips, hidden traces within the logic board's "sandwich" construction, and test pad layouts—information that simplifies fault tracing and board-level repairs.Security researchers could also identify potential hardware attack surfaces previously unknown to the public. Although competitors could theoretically obtain similar information by purchasing and disassembling an iPhone 16e—released in February 2025—the official schematics eliminate guesswork and provide Apple's authoritative technical specifications.Neither Apple nor the FCC has commented on the disclosure. The Commission appears to have removed the document from its official equipment authorisation site, though copies remain circulated online.
Article Summary: The Federal Communications Commission accidentally published confidential iPhone 16e schematics online. Apple specifically asked the FCC to withhold the document, stating they contain "confidential and proprietary trade secrets" The leak likely resulted from an incorrect database setting during the certification filing process, according to reports.

Article Title: Microsoft brings Windows engineering back together under Pavan Davuluri after six years; Davuluri Says: "This change…”
Article Text:
Reversing a six-year split in Windows development

Reorg aims to accelerate Microsoft’s vision of Agentic OS





Microsoft is consolidating its Windows engineering divisions under a single organisation for the first time since 2018, as the company pushes toward creating what it calls an "agentic OS" powered by artificial intelligence.Windows chief Pavan Davuluri, recently promoted to president of Windows and devices, announced the restructuring in an internal memo obtained by The Verge. The reorganisation brings together teams working on Windows client and server, along with divisions handling Core OS, Data Intelligence and Fundamentals, Security, and Engineering Systems—all now reporting directly to Davuluri."This change unifies Windows engineering work under a single organisation," Davuluri wrote, emphasising that consolidating these teams "brings focus to delivering against our priorities."The reunification reverses a 2018 decision that split Windows into separate divisions when former Windows chief Terry Myerson departed. At that time, Microsoft moved core Windows platform teams to Azure while client-facing features went to a new Experiences & Devices group. Though former Surface chief Panos Panay reclaimed some teams in 2020, most core engineering remained separate from consumer-facing Windows development until now.Some low-level components will still reside with Azure teams, including storage, networking, and the core kernel. "We will continue to have dependencies from the core kernel and virtualisation and Linux teams, now part of Azure Core," Davuluri noted in the memo.The restructuring directly supports Microsoft's vision of transforming Windows into an AI-first platform. Davuluri stated the reorganisation would help "deliver our vision of Windows as an Agentic OS"—referring to an operating system that can autonomously perform tasks on users' behalf.Microsoft has been aggressively integrating AI features into Windows 11, including the Windows AI Labs program for experimental capabilities, Copilot Vision tools, and an AI-powered Settings agent. The consolidated structure positions Davuluri to oversee this ambitious transformation as Microsoft reimagines its flagship operating system for the AI era.
Article Summary: Reorg aims to accelerate Microsoft’s vision of an Agentic OS. Reverses a six- year split in Windows development. Reorganisation brings together teams working on Windows client and server, along with divisions handling Core OS, Data Intelligence and Fundamentals.

Article Title: Asahi Group suspends operations in Japan after cyberattack

What is a cyberattack

The attack forced the UK-based car maker, which Tata Motors owns, to take its critical IT systems offline. The Tata Motors owned premium car company is now working to restore its systems and has warned that the production suspension could be extended. Beyond JLR's own facilities, the cyberattack has also caused significant disruption, with car sales being heavily impacted, forcing the company's network of parts suppliers to restrict their operations.

The models are designed to operate in tandem, improving a robot's reasoning, vision, and ability to execute actions in real-world settings.According to a blog shared by the company, this new two-model system will split the planning and execution tasks. Gemini Robotics-ER 1.5 will serve as the planner or orchestrator, determining the steps needed, while Gemini Robotics 1.5 is responsible for executing the physical functions based on natural language instructions.This separation is intended to overcome the limitations of earlier single-model systems, which often led to errors and delays when attempting to plan and perform actions simultaneously.The ER 1.5 model serves as a vision-language model (VLM) capable of advanced reasoning and integrating external tools. It can generate multi-step plans for tasks and shows strong performance on spatial understanding benchmarks. The model can also access resources, such as Google Search, to gather information and inform decision-making in physical environments.After a plan is created, Gemini Robotics 1.5, a vision-language-action (VLA) model, comes in. This model converts instructions and visual data into motor commands, allowing the robot to execute tasks. It determines the most efficient way to complete actions and can provide natural language explanations of its decisions.The system enables robots to handle complex, multi-step commands smoothly. For instance, a robot could sort items into compost, recycling, and trash bins by checking local recycling guidelines online, analysing objects, planning the sorting, and then executing the process.DeepMind notes that the AI models are adaptable to robots of various shapes and sizes due to their spatial awareness and flexible design. Currently, the ER 1.5 planner is available to developers via the Gemini API in Google AI Studio, while the VLA model is limited to select partners.This represents a step toward integrating generative AI into robotics, using natural language for control and separating planning from execution to reduce errors.
